title: How to Check if Your Computer Is 64 Bit

steps.title: Perform the following steps on your computer:
steps.content: Perform the following steps on your computer: Click on the Start Button. Type 'System' in the Start Search box Click "System" in the Programs list.

steps.title: Read the results.
steps.content: Read the results. In the "System" window it will state either "32-bit Operating System" or "64-bit Operating System".

steps.title: Press the WIN+R keys (Windows key and R).
steps.content: Press the WIN+R keys (Windows key and R). Type the following: sysdm.cpl and click OK.

steps.title: Click on "System Summary":
steps.content: Click on "System Summary": Under "System Type" it will either state "x86" if a 32-bit version of Windows is installed, or "EM64T" if a 64-bit version of Windows is installed.

steps.title: Type in the "Control Panel" search box.
steps.content: Type in the "Control Panel" search box.

steps.title: Click "Control Panel".
steps.content: Click "Control Panel". Next, press "System & Security". Press "System" and read the results.

steps.title: Open Windows Settings page.
steps.content: Open Windows Settings page. Open Windows Settings by pressing Win+I on the keyboard and the System page will be shown at first by default.

steps.title: Choose and view About.
steps.content: Choose and view About. Scroll down to About at the bottom of System. Click on it so you can view the information in System type .

steps.title: Type the following:
steps.content: Type the following: "uname -a" at the prompt. Note: do not use quotes. These were placed for emphasis. Note: ensure to insert the blank space between "uname" and "-a" strings.

steps.title: Read the text.
steps.content: Read the text. The terminal will display two lines of text. At the end of the second line, you will find wording such as: RELEASE_I386 i386 ; the latest "i386" means that you're running 32bits kernel RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64 ; the latest "x86_64" means that you're running 64bits kernel
